Many sports apparel brands have committed to implementing specific measures to address their environmental footprint and ensure fair treatment of workers in their supply chains. Here are a few examples:

1. Nike: Nike is working to reduce its carbon emissions and improve the sustainability of its products by using recycled materials, eliminating hazardous chemicals, and using more sustainable production methods. The company has also established labor standards for its suppliers and works to ensure that workers in its supply chain are treated fairly and work under safe conditions.

2. Adidas: Adidas has launched several initiatives to reduce its environmental footprint, including its "End Plastic Waste" campaign, which aims to eliminate the use of virgin plastics in its products by 2024. The company is also working to improve its labor practices and has established a Sustainability Board to oversee its progress in this area.

3. Puma: Puma has a stated goal of becoming the most sustainable sportswear company in the world by 2020. To achieve this goal, the company has committed to eliminating hazardous chemicals from its supply chain, reducing its carbon emissions, and using more sustainable materials in its products. Puma also works to ensure that workers in its supply chain are treated fairly and works with suppliers to improve labor conditions.

4. Under Armour: Under Armour has implemented a number of sustainable measures, including developing a more sustainable manufacturing process and using recycled materials in its products. The company has also established supplier guidelines for labor and environmental practices and works to ensure that workers in its supply chain are treated fairly.

Overall, while there is still work to be done to address the negative impact that sports apparel can have on the environment and local communities, many brands are making significant efforts to improve their practices and reduce their environmental footprint.
